candidates.title: Fix coloring when string has spaces
candidates.body:
The issue is here https://github.com/nushell/nushell/blob/e36649f74b37ee183a2b2999b5b3ee4762cb921a/crates/nu-table/src/wrap.rs#L93

When you split the lines you split ansi sequences.

I'd like to note that apparently now we don't handle this trailing space?

By the way why you need `Subline`s exactly?

close #5412

candidates.title: Add Miette "fancy" feature to fix plugin builds
candidates.body:
# Description

This PR is a short-term fix for a bug introduced in https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/5389 (my bad); after that change plugin builds were failing. Once the dust has settled, I'll think about longer term improvements:

- Have we ended up with the right solution for error printing? I'm not sure we have; maybe we'll end up moving this functionality to a crate other than `nu-protocol`
- We need to test plugin builds in CI, this should have been caught in CI

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

candidates.title: Openssl feature
candidates.body:
# Description

[As requested](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/5349#issuecomment-1111713557), moving the OpenSSL static linking from https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/5349 behind a feature (`static-link-openssl`).

I tested the release workflow as part of this and noticed that it was previously broken in https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/5272 (my bad - I didn't realize that `README.build.txt` was being included in releases). Fixed it up accordingly.

candidates.title: Statically link OpenSSL
candidates.body:
# Description

This PR statically links OpenSSL using [a feature of the `openssl` crate](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/). The hope is that this will address many of the support issues we see originating from dynamically linked OpenSSL.

Release build size goes up a bit from 15.8 MB to 18.1MB (Linux x64). I have manually tested the `nu` binary on Linux (and used `ldd` to confirm that it no longer uses OpenSSL shared libraries), and the builds+tests pass on all OSs.

Note: I needed to install the FindBin Perl tool (`dnf info perl-FindBin`) to get this to build on Fedora 36. Didn't need to tweak the GitHub CI config though.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

candidates.title: Add watch command
candidates.body:
This PR creates an experimental `watch` command:

```
〉help watch
Watch for file changes and execute Nu code when they happen.

Search terms: watcher, reload, filesystem

Usage:
  > watch {flags} <path> <block> 

Flags:
  -h, --help
      Display this help message
  -d, --debounce-ms <Int>
      Debounce changes for this many milliseconds (default: 100). Adjust if you find that single writes are reported as multiple events
  -g, --glob <String>
      Only report changes for files that match this glob pattern (default: all files)
  -r, --recursive <Boolean>
      Watch all directories under <path> recursively. Will be ignored if <path> is a file (default: true)
  -v, --verbose
      Operate in verbose mode (default: false)

Parameters:
  path: the path to watch. Can be a file or directory
  block: A Nu block of code to run whenever a file changes. The block will be passed `operation`, `path`, and `new_path` (for renames only) arguments in that order

Examples:
  Run `cargo test` whenever a Rust file changes
  > watch . --glob=**/*.rs { cargo test }

  Watch all changes in the current directory
  > watch . { |op, path, new_path| $"($op) ($path) ($new_path)"}

  Log all changes in a directory
  > watch /foo/bar { |op, path| $"($op) - ($path)(char nl)" | save --append changes_in_bar.log }
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26268125/165224711-e5c52527-a041-43c8-9ec3-79047b5579cc.png)

It uses [the popular `notify` crate](https://crates.io/crates/notify/4.0.17) to watch for file changes, and it runs in the foreground until the user presses `ctrl+c`.

## Motivation

I find myself using file watcher tools to automate tasks quite often; for example I'll want to run tests when my code changes, watch what a program is doing inside a directory, etc.

It's currently possible to use a tool like [`watchexec`](https://github.com/watchexec/watchexec) to launch a _new_ instance of Nu in response to file changes. But I think it might be more powerful and ergonomic to be able to respond to events without leaving Nu.

## Future work

- Currently this just queues up changes and runs the block in serial for each one. Might need to revisit that (maybe we'll want to batch changes if many arrive in a short period of time, or do some more work around cancellation?)
- I wasn't able to find a good way to display errors from the block with nice Miette formatting

## Build measurements
**Before PR:**  493 crates, 35.37s, 15.8 MiB
**After PR:** 502 crates, 36.42s, 16.0MiB

(`cargo build --release` on Linux w/ 12900K CPU, mold linker)

## Tests

I have tested manually on Linux and Windows.

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

candidates.title: Fuzzy completion matching
candidates.body:
# Description

This adds a new `MatchAlgorithm::Fuzzy` which uses the `fuzzy-completer` crate from skim (https://github.com/lotabout/fuzzy-matcher) to complete suggestions with a "fuzzy" search.

This is opt-in and can be enabled in the `config.nu` by setting the new `completion_algorithm` setting to `fuzzy` instead of the `prefix` default:

```
let-env config = {
  ...
  completion_algorithm: "fuzzy"
  ...
}
```

I developed and tested it on Windows so the fuzzy-matcher crate seems to support Windows even if skim itself does not.

Custom completions can still override completion options, although the `positional` and `case_sensitive` option has no effect at the moment if the `completion_algorithm` for this custom completion is `fuzzy`.

# Examples

```
> git out<tab>
> git checkout

> git checkout featcompl<tab>
> git checkout feature/new-completions

> echo $env.chome<tab>
> echo $env.CARGO_HOME
```

# Known Issues

* Completion may be slower than "prefix" completion
* `case_sensitive` option for custom commands does not work with fuzzy completion algorithm

# Future ideas

* Highlight matching chars
* Sort completions by matching score

candidates.title: update sys with new items, add kernel version to os-info
candidates.body:
# Description

This PR adds a few items to the `sys` command that were available but missing. Apparently the sysinfo crate has added new items since we wrote the sys command. I also took the opportunity to add kernel_version to $nu.os-info since it's helpful in distinguishing between WSL and Linux.

Hopefully there are no slow-downs at startup when populating $nu.os-info. If there is we can revert that part.

# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)

- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

candidates.title: Clean up tests and unused documentation code
candidates.body:
# Description

Pushed #4314 forward a bit:

- Updated `commands::select::allows_if_given_unknown_column_name_is_missing` to account for the new behavior of `select`
- Started trying to fix `commands::help::help_generate_docs_length`, but concluded that it's no longer necessary - and neither is a bunch of related code
  - A Discord search indicated that the `generate_docs` functionality never really went anywhere: "we had aspirations of generating help automagically when someone contributed generate_docs, and using it for the website somehow but, as I recall, it was like half implemented."
  - Pretty sure we can just get rid of all this now that we generate website docs with a Nu script

# Tests

candidates.title: Set to reedline main branch for development cycle
candidates.body:
# Changes to reedline since `v0.4.0`:

- vi normal mode `I` for inserting at line beginning
- `InsertNewline` edit command that can be bound to `Alt-Enter` if
desired to have line breaks without relying on the `Validator`
- `ClearScreen` will directly clear the visible screen. `Signal::CtrlL` has been
removed.
- `ClearScrollback` will clear the screen and scrollback. Can be used to
mimic macOS `Cmd-K` screen clearing. Helps with #5089


# Tests

Make sure you've run and fixed any issues with these commands:

- [x] `cargo fmt --all -- --check` to check standard code formatting (`cargo fmt --all` applies these changes)
- [x] `cargo clippy --all --all-features -- -D warnings -D clippy::unwrap_used -A clippy::needless_collect` to check that you're using the standard code style
- [x] `cargo build; cargo test --all --all-features` to check that all the tests pass

candidates.title: refactor html module
candidates.body:
# Description
Previously html 228_themes.json was loaded from a zip file which required the [zip](https://crates.io/crates/zip) crate to extract, this PR just load the json directly and removes the zip crate from the dependencies, this also reduces compile time because we don’t have to build bzip2 (see Cargo.lock)

# Tests
